description: Borrowed from French busc, by dissimilation (from buste) from Italian busto. Doublet of bust.

entries.meaning: A strip of metal, whalebone, wood, or other material, worn in the front of a corset to stiffen it.
examples: Her long slit sleeves, stiffe buske, puffe verdingall, / Is all that makes her thus angelicall.
Off with that happy busk, which I envie, / That still can be, and still can stand so nigh.
Busk, a kind of table linen, occurs first in 1458, and occasionally afterwards.

description: From Middle English busken, from Old Norse b√∫ask.

verbs.description: busk (third-person singular simple present busks, present participle busking, simple past and past participle busked)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To prepare; to make ready; to array; to dress.
examples: Busk ye, busk ye, my bonny, bonny bride.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To go; to direct one's course.
examples: Ye might have busked you to Huntly-banks.

description: Apparently from French busquer or Spanish buscar.

verbs.description: busk (third-person singular simple present busks, present participle busking, simple past and past participle busked)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To solicit money by entertaining the public in the street or in public transport.
(intransitive, obsolete) To sell articles such as obscene books in public houses etc.
examples: The frothy orator, who busked his tales In quackish pomp of noisy words
